    A Brief Introduction to Virtuoso

    Carl Boettiger

    2018-11-06

    readme.Rmd

    virtuoso

    The goal of virtuoso is to provide an easy interface to Virtuoso RDF database from R.

    Installation

    You can install the development version of virtuoso from GitHub with:

    remotes::install_github("cboettig/virtuoso")

    Linux users should install Virtuoso server from their package manager.

    Getting Started

    library(virtuoso)

    For Mac users, virtuoso package includes a utility function to install and configure a local Virtuoso Open Source instance using Homebrew. Otherwise, simply install the Virtuoso Open Source edition for your operating system.

    vos_install()
#> virtuoso already installed.

    We can now start our Virtuoso server from R:

    vos_start()
#> PROCESS 'virtuoso-t', running, pid 66427.
#> 
#>      Tue Nov 06 2018
#> 14:56:01 { Loading plugin 1: Type `plain', file `wikiv' in `/usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting'
#> 14:56:01   WikiV version 0.6 from OpenLink Software
#> 14:56:01   Support functions for WikiV collaboration tool
#> 14:56:01   SUCCESS plugin 1: loaded from /usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting/wikiv.so }
#> 14:56:01 { Loading plugin 2: Type `plain', file `mediawiki' in `/usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting'
#> 14:56:01   MediaWiki version 0.1 from OpenLink Software
#> 14:56:01   Support functions for MediaWiki collaboration tool
#> 14:56:01   SUCCESS plugin 2: loaded from /usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting/mediawiki.so }
#> 14:56:01 { Loading plugin 3: Type `plain', file `creolewiki' in `/usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting'
#> 14:56:01   CreoleWiki version 0.1 from OpenLink Software
#> 14:56:01   Support functions for CreoleWiki collaboration tool
#> 14:56:01   SUCCESS plugin 3: loaded from /usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting/creolewiki.so }
#> 14:56:01 OpenLink Virtuoso Universal Server
#> 14:56:01 Version 07.20.3229-pthreads for Darwin as of Aug 24 2018
#> 14:56:01 uses parts of OpenSSL, PCRE, Html Tidy
#> 14:56:01 Database version 3126
#> 14:56:01 SQL Optimizer enabled (max 1000 layouts)
#> 14:56:02 Compiler unit is timed at 0.000276 msec
#> 14:56:04 Roll forward started
#> 14:56:04     6 transactions, 377 bytes replayed (100 %)
#> 14:56:04 Roll forward complete
#> 14:56:05 PL LOG: Can't get list of vad packages in /usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/share/virtuoso/vad/
#> 14:56:05 Checkpoint started
#> 14:56:06 Checkpoint finished, log reused
#> 14:56:08 HTTP/WebDAV server online at 8890
#> 14:56:08 Server online at 1111 (pid 66427)

    Once the server is running, we can connect to the database.

    con <- vos_connect()

    Our connection is now live, and accepts SPARQL queries directly.

    ex <- DBI::dbGetQuery(con, "SPARQL SELECT * WHERE { ?s ?p ?o }")

    DSL

    virtuoso also provides wrappers around some common queries to make it easier to work with Virtuoso and RDF.

    The bulk loader can be used to quickly import existing sets of triples.

    example <- system.file("extdata", "person.nq", package = "virtuoso")
vos_import(con, example)
    df <- vos_query(con, 
"SELECT DISTINCT ?p ?o 
 WHERE { ?s ?p ?o .
        ?s a <http://schema.org/Person>
       }")
df
#>                                                 p                        o
#> 1 http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#type http://schema.org/Person
#> 2                      http://schema.org/jobTitle                Professor
#> 3                     http://schema.org/telephone           (425) 123-4567
#> 4                           http://schema.org/url   http://www.janedoe.com
#> 5                          http://schema.org/name                 Jane Doe

    We can clear all data in the default graph if we want a fresh start:

    vos_clear_graph(con)
#> data frame with 0 columns and 0 rows

    Server controls

    We can control any virtuoso server started with vos_start() using a series of helper commands.

    vos_status()
#> 
#>      Tue Nov 06 2018
#> 14:56:01 { Loading plugin 1: Type `plain', file `wikiv' in `/usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting'
#> 14:56:01   WikiV version 0.6 from OpenLink Software
#> 14:56:01   Support functions for WikiV collaboration tool
#> 14:56:01   SUCCESS plugin 1: loaded from /usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting/wikiv.so }
#> 14:56:01 { Loading plugin 2: Type `plain', file `mediawiki' in `/usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting'
#> 14:56:01   MediaWiki version 0.1 from OpenLink Software
#> 14:56:01   Support functions for MediaWiki collaboration tool
#> 14:56:01   SUCCESS plugin 2: loaded from /usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting/mediawiki.so }
#> 14:56:01 { Loading plugin 3: Type `plain', file `creolewiki' in `/usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting'
#> 14:56:01   CreoleWiki version 0.1 from OpenLink Software
#> 14:56:01   Support functions for CreoleWiki collaboration tool
#> 14:56:01   SUCCESS plugin 3: loaded from /usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/lib/virtuoso/hosting/creolewiki.so }
#> 14:56:01 OpenLink Virtuoso Universal Server
#> 14:56:01 Version 07.20.3229-pthreads for Darwin as of Aug 24 2018
#> 14:56:01 uses parts of OpenSSL, PCRE, Html Tidy
#> 14:56:01 Database version 3126
#> 14:56:01 SQL Optimizer enabled (max 1000 layouts)
#> 14:56:02 Compiler unit is timed at 0.000276 msec
#> 14:56:04 Roll forward started
#> 14:56:04     6 transactions, 377 bytes replayed (100 %)
#> 14:56:04 Roll forward complete
#> 14:56:05 PL LOG: Can't get list of vad packages in /usr/local/Cellar/virtuoso/7.2.5.1/share/virtuoso/vad/
#> 14:56:05 Checkpoint started
#> 14:56:06 Checkpoint finished, log reused
#> 14:56:08 HTTP/WebDAV server online at 8890
#> 14:56:08 Server online at 1111 (pid 66427)
#> 14:56:08 PL LOG: Loader started
#> 14:56:08 PL LOG: No more files to load. Loader has finished,
#> [1] "running"

    Advanced usage note: vos_start() invisibly returns a processx object which we can pass to other server control functions, or access the embedded processx control methods directly. The virtuoso package also caches this object in an environment so that it can be accessed directly without having to keep track of an object in the global environment. Use vos_process() to return the processx object. For example:

    p <- vos_process()
p$get_error_file()
#> [1] "/var/folders/y8/0wn724zs10jd79_srhxvy49r0000gn/T/RtmpLeULY3/vos_start102d6751230a6.log"
p$suspend()
#> NULL
p$resume()
#> NULL

    See richer examples in the package vignettes.
